body: Pancakes. Waffles are great because they're crispy and have little syrup boxes but I think pancakes are better for mix-ins. Chocolate chips, strawberries, bananas, peanut butter, bacon and so on. You can add them to waffles but they don't cook the same. I also like the pancake mush that's left on the plate near the end that's drenched in syrup.
body_html: Pancakes. Waffles are great because they're crispy and have little syrup boxes but I think pancakes are better for mix-ins. Chocolate chips, strawberries, bananas, peanut butter, bacon and so on. You can add them to waffles but they don't cook the same. I also like the pancake mush that's left on the plate near the end that's drenched in syrup.

post.title: I am going to ask the biggest question of AskRuqqus

body:
I'm going to copy a comment from Dave Rapp at http://www.all-night-laundry.com/post/1350 which I find absolutely funny.

"Let me tell you about waffles. Waffles are a food that's made by someone who just doesn't care anymore. Waffles are what happens when a pancake gets greedy. Waffles are an attempt at taking a cake-based food and frying it, except we already have foods like that, and they aren't for breakfast, they're for selling at stalls at a carnival. A waffle is a halfbaked (pun not intended) attempt at cooking in three dimensions. You want a bread-like food that cooks on both sides at the same time? I have a question - WHY would you want that? Omnidirectional cooking is how you get overly crispy things. Waffles are crust.

AND THEN... the barbarians who eat such garbage have the gall to smother the fucking things in syrup, when we all know that syrup belongs on one and only one things - a fucking PANCAKE. And this takes us to the heart of the matter - waffles ARE pancakes. They're pancakes that put on airs and tried to get all golden and crispy because somebody told them that people like crispy food. And it's true, people do like crispy food, but do you know what happens when you put syrup on a waffle? I'll tell you what it doesn't do:

It doesn't stay fucking crispy.

In a perfect world, I.E. not the world we live in, a waffle would retain its warm golden crispy goodness while being slathered in syrup. But that's not what happens, is it? The syrup is room temperature, or sometimes it's even COLD depending on where you store it and what time of year it is. Meanwhile the waffles are warm, just out of the iron - or let's be realistic, you probably got them out of the toaster because frozen waffles are the same shit but cheaper. What happens when you mix warm and not warm? You get fucking lukewarm sludge. This is acceptable with a pancake because pancakes are basically just floppy bullshit anyway, but a waffle? A warm, crispy, golden waffle? That fucker gets ruined. The syrup collects in the little square pore things and just sits there, demonstrating the laws of thermodynamics, sucking the heat from what was previously a warm food item.

The end result is just a mess. You have a poorly defined gold sludge, shaped like a circle or a square or whatever, and what are you even supposed to do with it? You have to eat it with a knife and fork but when you cut into it you rupture those pores, and then WOOPS I ACCIDENTALLY ALL THIS SYRUP. The syrup, which has already ruined this brown mass of solid crust doesn't even have the decency to stick around. It's going right onto the plate - or, because syrup is a nonnewtonian fluid and doesn't drip as fast as water, half of it drips into your lap, and now you have to do laundry. YOU HAVE TO DO LAUNDRY! HAPPY FUCKING BREAKFAST JACKASS!!

https://uploads.disquscdn.com/images/427dcda2de57957c503162b4d777109af20f6063f5f23dcfb1b7d8d6acee09c4.png"

btw, awesome webcomic 100% worth the read, just make sure to reset your PTP before you start reading (green bar at top)

author.bio: I am a professional asshole.

body: Pancakes are just way too meh, it’s just a plain cake. Meanwhile waffles are their own thing. They have a unique shape, a special kind of crunch that isn’t like a biscuit or other things like that, waffles have a distinct tang to add to their taste, they have a not too fluffy inside, and you can even buy a box of frozen ones that fit easily in toasters and heat up well. You can easily hold one, even if it is soaked in syrup, because they’re not floppy, they are equally great when eaten by hand or fork, and can even make temporary tiny maple syrup pools.
body_html: Pancakes are just way too meh, it’s just a plain cake. Meanwhile waffles are their own thing. They have a unique shape, a special kind of crunch that isn’t like a biscuit or other things like that, waffles have a distinct tang to add to their taste, they have a not too fluffy inside, and you can even buy a box of frozen ones that fit easily in toasters and heat up well. You can easily hold one, even if it is soaked in syrup, because they’re not floppy, they are equally great when eaten by hand or fork, and can even make temporary tiny maple syrup pools.

parent.body: Pancakes are just way too meh, it’s just a plain cake. Meanwhile waffles are their own thing. They have a unique shape, a special kind of crunch that isn’t like a biscuit or other things like that, waffles have a distinct tang to add to their taste, they have a not too fluffy inside, and you can even buy a box of frozen ones that fit easily in toasters and heat up well. You can easily hold one, even if it is soaked in syrup, because they’re not floppy, they are equally great when eaten by hand or fork, and can even make temporary tiny maple syrup pools.

parent.body:
I'm going to copy a comment from Dave Rapp at http://www.all-night-laundry.com/post/1350 which I find absolutely funny.

"Let me tell you about waffles. Waffles are a food that's made by someone who just doesn't care anymore. Waffles are what happens when a pancake gets greedy. Waffles are an attempt at taking a cake-based food and frying it, except we already have foods like that, and they aren't for breakfast, they're for selling at stalls at a carnival. A waffle is a halfbaked (pun not intended) attempt at cooking in three dimensions. You want a bread-like food that cooks on both sides at the same time? I have a question - WHY would you want that? Omnidirectional cooking is how you get overly crispy things. Waffles are crust.

AND THEN... the barbarians who eat such garbage have the gall to smother the fucking things in syrup, when we all know that syrup belongs on one and only one things - a fucking PANCAKE. And this takes us to the heart of the matter - waffles ARE pancakes. They're pancakes that put on airs and tried to get all golden and crispy because somebody told them that people like crispy food. And it's true, people do like crispy food, but do you know what happens when you put syrup on a waffle? I'll tell you what it doesn't do:

It doesn't stay fucking crispy.

In a perfect world, I.E. not the world we live in, a waffle would retain its warm golden crispy goodness while being slathered in syrup. But that's not what happens, is it? The syrup is room temperature, or sometimes it's even COLD depending on where you store it and what time of year it is. Meanwhile the waffles are warm, just out of the iron - or let's be realistic, you probably got them out of the toaster because frozen waffles are the same shit but cheaper. What happens when you mix warm and not warm? You get fucking lukewarm sludge. This is acceptable with a pancake because pancakes are basically just floppy bullshit anyway, but a waffle? A warm, crispy, golden waffle? That fucker gets ruined. The syrup collects in the little square pore things and just sits there, demonstrating the laws of thermodynamics, sucking the heat from what was previously a warm food item.

The end result is just a mess. You have a poorly defined gold sludge, shaped like a circle or a square or whatever, and what are you even supposed to do with it? You have to eat it with a knife and fork but when you cut into it you rupture those pores, and then WOOPS I ACCIDENTALLY ALL THIS SYRUP. The syrup, which has already ruined this brown mass of solid crust doesn't even have the decency to stick around. It's going right onto the plate - or, because syrup is a nonnewtonian fluid and doesn't drip as fast as water, half of it drips into your lap, and now you have to do laundry. YOU HAVE TO DO LAUNDRY! HAPPY FUCKING BREAKFAST JACKASS!!

https://uploads.disquscdn.com/images/427dcda2de57957c503162b4d777109af20f6063f5f23dcfb1b7d8d6acee09c4.png"

btw, awesome webcomic 100% worth the read, just make sure to reset your PTP before you start reading (green bar at top)

post.title: I am going to ask the biggest question of AskRuqqus

body:
Taste: Waffles-5, Pancakes-4  
  
Texture: Waffles-5, Pancakes-4  
  
Buttered- Waffles-4, Pancakes-5  
  
Syruped- Waffles-4, Pancakes-5  
 
Fresh Toppings- Waffles-5, Pancakes-5  
  
Whipped Cream- Waffles-5, Pancakes-5  
  
Mix-Ins- Waffles-3, Pancakes-5  
  
Portability- Waffles-5, Pancakes-4  
  
Variations- Waffles-4, Pancakes-5  
  
Pancakes take the cake, not by much, it was mix-ups that really put pancakes over the edge! I thought portability was going to bring waffles back, but you can't eat a hot Waffle on the way to your car in the morning.
body_html:
Taste: Waffles-5, Pancakes-4

Texture: Waffles-5, Pancakes-4

Buttered- Waffles-4, Pancakes-5

Syruped- Waffles-4, Pancakes-5

Fresh Toppings- Waffles-5, Pancakes-5

Whipped Cream- Waffles-5, Pancakes-5

Mix-Ins- Waffles-3, Pancakes-5

Portability- Waffles-5, Pancakes-4

Variations- Waffles-4, Pancakes-5

Pancakes take the cake, not by much, it was mix-ups that really put pancakes over the edge! I thought portability was going to bring waffles back, but you can't eat a hot Waffle on the way to your car in the morning.
